1→# Apollo R Plumber API — Sprint 7-8: Statistical Analysis Endpoints
     2→# All analyses are pre-defined functions. No raw R code execution.
     3→
     4→library(plumber)
     5→library(jsonlite)
     6→library(dplyr)
     7→library(gtsummary)
     8→library(ggplot2)
     9→library(broom)
    10→library(base64enc)
    11→library(readr)
    12→
    13→# ── Helper functions ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    14→
    15→#' Convert a data.frame to LaTeX table (publication-ready)
    16→to_latex_table <- function(df, caption = "Results") {
    17→  # Basic LaTeX table output
    18→  header <- paste0("\\begin{table}[htbp]\n\\centering\n\\caption{", caption, "}\n")
    19→  col_align <- paste(rep("l", ncol(df)), collapse = "")
    20→  begin <- paste0("\\begin{tabular}{", col_align, "}\n\\hline\n")
    21→
    22→  # Header row
    23→  header_row <- paste(names(df), collapse = " & ")
    24→  header_row <- paste0(header_row, " \\\\\n\\hline\n")
    25→
    26→  # Data rows
    27→  data_rows <- apply(df, 1, function(row) {
    28→    paste(row, collapse = " & ")
    29→  })
    30→  data_section <- paste(data_rows, collapse = " \\\\\n")
    31→  data_section <- paste0(data_section, " \\\\\n\\hline\n")
    32→
    33→  end <- "\\end{tabular}\n\\end{table}"
    34→  paste0(header, begin, header_row, data_section, end)
    35→}
    36→
    37→#' Save ggplot to temporary PDF, return base64
    38→save_plot_base64 <- function(plot, filename = "plot.pdf", width = 7, height = 5) {
    39→  filepath <- file.path(tempdir(), filename)
    40→  ggsave(filepath, plot, width = width, height = height, dpi = 300, device = "pdf")
    41→  encoded <- base64encode(filepath)
    42→  unlink(filepath)
    43→  list(filename = filename, base64 = encoded)
    44→}
    45→
    46→#' Parse incoming data safely
    47→parse_data <- function(data) {
    48→  df <- as.data.frame(data, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
    49→  # Auto-convert numeric columns
    50→  for (col in names(df)) {
    51→    numeric_vals <- suppressWarnings(as.numeric(df[[col]]))
    52→    if (sum(!is.na(numeric_vals)) / max(sum(!is.na(df[[col]])), 1) > 0.8) {
    53→      df[[col]] <- numeric_vals
    54→    }
    55→  }
    56→  df
    57→}
    58→
    59→#' Apply colour scheme to a ggplot
    60→apply_colour_scheme <- function(plot, colour_scheme = "default") {
    61→  if (is.null(colour_scheme) || colour_scheme == "default") {
    62→    return(plot)
    63→  }
    64→  if (colour_scheme == "greyscale") {
    65→    return(plot + scale_fill_grey() + scale_colour_grey() + theme_minimal())
    66→  }
    67→  if (colour_scheme == "colourblind-safe") {
    68→    cb_palette <- c("#E69F00", "#56B4E9", "#009E73", "#F0E442", "#0072B2", "#D55E00", "#CC79A7", "#999999")
    69→    return(plot + scale_fill_manual(values = cb_palette) + scale_colour_manual(values = cb_palette))
    70→  }
    71→  plot
    72→}
    73→
    74→# ── Authentication filter ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    75→
    76→#* @plumber
    77→function(pr) {
    78→  secret <- Sys.getenv("R_PLUMBER_SECRET", "")
    79→  if (nzchar(secret)) {
    80→    pr %>% plumber::pr_filter("auth", function(req, res) {
    81→      # Allow health check without auth for Docker healthcheck
    82→      if (req$PATH_INFO == "/health") {
    83→        return(plumber::forward())
    84→      }
    85→      auth_header <- req$HTTP_AUTHORIZATION
    86→      if (is.null(auth_header) || auth_header != paste0("Bearer ", secret)) {
    87→        res$status <- 401L
    88→        return(list(error = "Unauthorised"))
    89→      }
    90→      plumber::forward()
    91→    })
    92→  }
    93→}
    94→
    95→# ── Health check ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
    96→
    97→#* Health check
    98→#* @get /health
    99→function() {
   100→  list(
   101→    status = "ok",
   102→    service = "apollo-r-plumber",
   103→    r_version = paste(R.version$major, R.version$minor, sep = "."),
   104→    timestamp = Sys.time(),
   105→    packages = list(
   106→      survival = requireNamespace("survival", quietly = TRUE),
   107→      pROC = requireNamespace("pROC", quietly = TRUE),
   108→      meta = requireNamespace("meta", quietly = TRUE)
   109→    )
   110→  )
   111→}
   112→
   113→# ── Descriptive Statistics ────────────────────────────────────────────────────
   114→
   115→#* Descriptive statistics using gtsummary
   116→#* @post /descriptive
   117→#* @serializer unboxedJSON
   118→function(req) {
   119→  tryCatch({
   120→    setTimeLimit(cpu = 15, elapsed = 15, transient = TRUE)
   121→    on.exit(setTimeLimit(cpu = Inf, elapsed = Inf, transient = FALSE), add = TRUE)
   122→    body <- req$body
   123→    df <- parse_data(body$data)
   124→    group_col <- body$group
   125→
   126→    if (!is.null(group_col) && group_col %in% names(df)) {
   127→      tbl <- tbl_summary(df, by = all_of(group_col),
   128→                         missing = "ifany",
   129→                         statistic = list(
   130→                           all_continuous() ~ "{mean} ({sd})",
   131→                           all_categorical() ~ "{n} ({p}%)"
   132→                         )) %>%
   133→        add_p() %>%
   134→        add_overall()
   135→    } else {
   136→      tbl <- tbl_summary(df,
   137→                         missing = "ifany",
   138→                         statistic = list(
   139→                           all_continuous() ~ "{mean} ({sd})",
   140→                           all_categorical() ~ "{n} ({p}%)"
   141→                         ))
   142→    }
   143→
   144→    # Extract as data frame for JSON
   145→    tbl_df <- as_tibble(tbl)
   146→
   147→    # Generate LaTeX table
   148→    latex_tbl <- to_latex_table(tbl_df, "Descriptive Statistics")
   149→
   150→    # Generate R script for reproducibility
   151→    r_script <- paste0(
   152→      "library(gtsummary)\n",
   153→      "# Descriptive statistics\n",
   154→      if (!is.null(group_col)) paste0("tbl_summary(data, by = \"", group_col, "\") %>% add_p() %>% add_overall()\n")
   155→      else "tbl_summary(data)\n"
   156→    )
   157→
   158→    list(
   159→      summary = tbl_df,
   160→      table_latex = latex_tbl,
   161→      figures = list(),
   162→      warnings = list(),
   163→      r_script = r_script
   164→    )
   165→  }, error = function(e) {
   166→    list(error = e$message)
   167→  })
   168→}
   169→
   170→# ── Chi-Square / Fisher's Test ────────────────────────────────────────────────
   171→
   172→#* Chi-square or Fisher's exact test (auto-selected by cell count)
   173→#* @post /chi-square
   174→#* @serializer unboxedJSON
   175→function(req) {
   176→  tryCatch({
   177→    setTimeLimit(cpu = 30, elapsed = 30, transient = TRUE)
   178→    on.exit(setTimeLimit(cpu = Inf, elapsed = Inf, transient = FALSE), add = TRUE)
   179→    body <- req$body
   180→    df <- parse_data(body$data)
   181→    outcome <- body$outcome
   182→    predictor <- body$predictor
   183→
   184→    if (is.null(outcome) || is.null(predictor)) {
   185→      return(list(error = "outcome and predictor columns required"))
   186→    }
   187→
   188→    tbl <- table(df[[predictor]], df[[outcome]])
   189→
   190→    # Auto-select: Fisher's if any expected cell count < 5
   191→    expected <- chisq.test(tbl)$expected
   192→    use_fisher <- any(expected < 5)
   193→
   194→    if (use_fisher) {
   195→      test_result <- fisher.test(tbl, simulate.p.value = (nrow(tbl) > 2 || ncol(tbl) > 2))
   196→      test_name <- "Fisher's Exact Test"
   197→    } else {
   198→      test_result <- chisq.test(tbl)
   199→      test_name <- "Chi-Square Test"
   200→    }

1→#!/usr/bin/env bash
     2→# deploy-conformance.sh — VPS deploy-gate conformance checks
     3→# Referenced by docs/governance/security-tests.md and release-gates.md
     4→# Exit 1 on any FAIL. Prints [PASS]/[WARN]/[FAIL] per check.
     5→set -euo pipefail
     6→
     7→SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "$0")" && pwd)"
     8→REPO_ROOT="$(cd "$SCRIPT_DIR/.." && pwd)"
     9→
    10→PASS=0
    11→WARN=0
    12→FAIL=0
    13→
    14→pass() { echo "[PASS] $1"; PASS=$((PASS + 1)); }
    15→warn() { echo "[WARN] $1"; WARN=$((WARN + 1)); }
    16→fail() { echo "[FAIL] $1"; FAIL=$((FAIL + 1)); }
    17→
    18→echo "=== Apollo Deploy Conformance Checks ==="
    19→echo ""
    20→
    21→# ─── 1. LaTeX seccomp profile exists and is valid JSON ───
    22→SECCOMP_LATEX="$REPO_ROOT/docker/seccomp-latex.json"
    23→if [ -f "$SECCOMP_LATEX" ]; then
    24→  if jq empty "$SECCOMP_LATEX" 2>/dev/null; then
    25→    pass "LaTeX seccomp profile exists and is valid JSON"
    26→  else
    27→    fail "LaTeX seccomp profile is not valid JSON"
    28→  fi
    29→else
    30→  fail "LaTeX seccomp profile not found at $SECCOMP_LATEX"
    31→fi
    32→
    33→# ─── 2. LaTeX test compilation with security flags ───
    34→if command -v docker &>/dev/null && docker image inspect apollo-latex &>/dev/null; then
    35→  TEST_DIR=$(mktemp -d)
    36→  cat > "$TEST_DIR/main.tex" <<'LATEX'
    37→\documentclass{article}
    38→\begin{document}
    39→Hello, Apollo conformance test.
    40→\end{document}
    41→LATEX
    42→
    43→  DOCKER_ARGS=(
    44→    run --rm
    45→    --network=none --read-only
    46→    --tmpfs /tmp:rw,size=512m
    47→    --memory=1g --pids-limit=256
    48→    --security-opt no-new-privileges:true
    49→    --cap-drop=ALL --cap-add=DAC_OVERRIDE --cap-add=FOWNER
    50→  )
    51→
    52→  # Add seccomp profile if on Linux (not macOS)
    53→  if [ "$(uname -s)" = "Linux" ] && [ -f "$SECCOMP_LATEX" ]; then
    54→    DOCKER_ARGS+=(--security-opt "seccomp=$SECCOMP_LATEX")
    55→  fi
    56→
    57→  DOCKER_ARGS+=(-v "$TEST_DIR:/thesis" apollo-latex)
    58→
    59→  if docker "${DOCKER_ARGS[@]}" 2>/dev/null; then
    60→    pass "LaTeX test compilation succeeded with security flags"
    61→  else
    62→    fail "LaTeX test compilation failed with security flags"
    63→  fi
    64→  rm -rf "$TEST_DIR"
    65→else
    66→  warn "Docker or apollo-latex image not available — skipping compile test"
    67→fi
    68→
    69→# ─── 3. R Plumber seccomp profile exists and is valid JSON ───
    70→SECCOMP_R="$REPO_ROOT/docker/seccomp-r.json"
    71→if [ -f "$SECCOMP_R" ]; then
    72→  if jq empty "$SECCOMP_R" 2>/dev/null; then
    73→    pass "R Plumber seccomp profile exists and is valid JSON"
    74→  else
    75→    fail "R Plumber seccomp profile is not valid JSON"
    76→  fi
    77→else
    78→  fail "R Plumber seccomp profile not found at $SECCOMP_R"
    79→fi
    80→
    81→# ─── 4. R Plumber container is running and healthy ───
    82→if command -v docker &>/dev/null; then
    83→  R_STATUS=$(docker inspect --format='{{.State.Health.Status}}' apollo-r-plumber 2>/dev/null || echo "not_found")
    84→  if [ "$R_STATUS" = "healthy" ]; then
    85→    pass "R Plumber container is healthy"
    86→  elif [ "$R_STATUS" = "not_found" ]; then
    87→    warn "R Plumber container not running — skipping health check"
    88→  else
    89→    fail "R Plumber container status: $R_STATUS (expected: healthy)"
    90→  fi
    91→else
    92→  warn "Docker not available — skipping R Plumber health check"
    93→fi
    94→
    95→# ─── 5. R Plumber seccomp is NOT unconfined ───
    96→if command -v docker &>/dev/null && docker inspect apollo-r-plumber &>/dev/null 2>&1; then
    97→  SECCOMP_SETTING=$(docker inspect --format='{{range .HostConfig.SecurityOpt}}{{.}}{{"\n"}}{{end}}' apollo-r-plumber 2>/dev/null | grep seccomp || echo "")
    98→  if echo "$SECCOMP_SETTING" | grep -q "unconfined"; then
    99→    fail "R Plumber is running with seccomp:unconfined"
   100→  elif [ -n "$SECCOMP_SETTING" ]; then
   101→    pass "R Plumber seccomp is not unconfined"
   102→  else
   103→    warn "Could not determine R Plumber seccomp setting"
   104→  fi
   105→else
   106→  warn "R Plumber container not available — skipping seccomp check"
   107→fi
   108→
   109→# ─── 6. AppArmor profile loaded (warn-only) ───
   110→if [ "$(uname -s)" = "Linux" ] && command -v aa-status &>/dev/null; then
   111→  if aa-status 2>/dev/null | grep -q "apollo-r-plumber"; then
   112→    pass "AppArmor profile 'apollo-r-plumber' is loaded"
   113→  else
   114→    warn "AppArmor profile 'apollo-r-plumber' not loaded (load with: sudo apparmor_parser -r $REPO_ROOT/docker/apparmor-r-plumber)"
   115→  fi
   116→else
   117→  warn "AppArmor not available on this system (macOS or missing aa-status)"
   118→fi
   119→
   120→# ─── 7. No system() calls in plumber.R ───
   121→PLUMBER_R="$REPO_ROOT/docker/plumber.R"
   122→if [ -f "$PLUMBER_R" ]; then
   123→  if grep -qE 'system\s*\(|system2\s*\(' "$PLUMBER_R"; then
   124→    fail "plumber.R contains system() or system2() calls — potential command injection"
   125→  else
   126→    pass "No system() calls in plumber.R"
   127→  fi
   128→else
   129→  warn "plumber.R not found — skipping system() check"
   130→fi
   131→
   132→# ─── 8. No dangerous bind mounts ───
   133→DANGEROUS_MOUNTS="/etc /home /root /proc /sys"
   134→MOUNT_FAIL=0
   135→if command -v docker &>/dev/null; then
   136→  for CONTAINER in apollo-latex apollo-r-plumber; do
   137→    MOUNTS=$(docker inspect --format='{{range .Mounts}}{{.Source}}:{{.Destination}} {{end}}' "$CONTAINER" 2>/dev/null || echo "")
   138→    for DANGER in $DANGEROUS_MOUNTS; do
   139→      if echo "$MOUNTS" | grep -q "$DANGER"; then
   140→        fail "Container $CONTAINER has dangerous bind mount: $DANGER"
   141→        MOUNT_FAIL=1
   142→      fi
   143→    done
   144→  done
   145→  if [ "$MOUNT_FAIL" -eq 0 ]; then
   146→    pass "No dangerous bind mounts detected"
   147→  fi
   148→else
   149→  warn "Docker not available — skipping bind mount check"
   150→fi
   151→
   152→# ─── 9. No API secrets leaked to compute containers ───
   153→SECRET_LEAK=0
   154→if command -v docker &>/dev/null; then
   155→  for CONTAINER in apollo-latex apollo-r-plumber; do
   156→    ENV_VARS=$(docker inspect --format='{{range .Config.Env}}{{.}} {{end}}' "$CONTAINER" 2>/dev/null || echo "")
   157→    for SECRET_KEY in ANTHROPIC_API_KEY SUPABASE_SERVICE_ROLE_KEY CLERK_SECRET_KEY SENTRY_AUTH_TOKEN; do
   158→      if echo "$ENV_VARS" | grep -q "$SECRET_KEY"; then
   159→        fail "Container $CONTAINER has $SECRET_KEY in environment"
   160→        SECRET_LEAK=1
   161→      fi
   162→    done
   163→  done
   164→  if [ "$SECRET_LEAK" -eq 0 ]; then
   165→    pass "No API secrets leaked to compute containers"
   166→  fi
   167→else
   168→  warn "Docker not available — skipping secret leak check"
   169→fi
   170→
   171→# ─── 10. SSL certificate validity ───
   172→DOMAIN="${APOLLO_DOMAIN:-}"
   173→if [ -n "$DOMAIN" ]; then
   174→  EXPIRY=$(echo | openssl s_client -servername "$DOMAIN" -connect "$DOMAIN:443" 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -enddate 2>/dev/null | cut -d= -f2)
   175→  if [ -n "$EXPIRY" ]; then
   176→    EXPIRY_EPOCH=$(date -d "$EXPIRY" +%s 2>/dev/null || date -jf "%b %d %T %Y %Z" "$EXPIRY" +%s 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
   177→    NOW_EPOCH=$(date +%s)
   178→    DAYS_LEFT=$(( (EXPIRY_EPOCH - NOW_EPOCH) / 86400 ))
   179→    if [ "$DAYS_LEFT" -lt 14 ]; then
   180→      fail "SSL certificate expires in $DAYS_LEFT days (< 14 day threshold)"
   181→    else
   182→      pass "SSL certificate valid ($DAYS_LEFT days remaining)"
   183→    fi
   184→  else
   185→    warn "Could not determine SSL expiry for $DOMAIN"
   186→  fi
   187→else
   188→  warn "APOLLO_DOMAIN not set — skipping SSL check"
   189→fi
   190→
   191→# ─── 11. No unexpected open ports ───
   192→if [ "$(uname -s)" = "Linux" ] && command -v ss &>/dev/null; then
   193→  EXPECTED_PORTS="3000 8787 443 80 22"
   194→  UNEXPECTED=$(ss -tlnp 2>/dev/null | awk 'NR>1 {print $4}' | grep -oE '[0-9]+$' | sort -u | while read -r PORT; do
   195→    FOUND=0
   196→    for EP in $EXPECTED_PORTS; do
   197→      if [ "$PORT" = "$EP" ]; then FOUND=1; break; fi
   198→    done
   199→    if [ "$FOUND" -eq 0 ]; then echo "$PORT"; fi
   200→  done)
   201→  if [ -n "$UNEXPECTED" ]; then
   202→    warn "Unexpected open ports detected: $UNEXPECTED"
   203→  else
   204→    pass "No unexpected open ports"
   205→  fi
   206→else
   207→  warn "Port scan not available (macOS or missing ss) — skipping"
   208→fi
   209→
   210→# ─── Summary ───
   211→echo ""
   212→echo "=== Summary ==="
   213→echo "PASS: $PASS  WARN: $WARN  FAIL: $FAIL"
   214→
   215→if [ "$FAIL" -gt 0 ]; then
   216→  echo ""
   217→  echo "Deploy gate FAILED — fix all FAIL items before deploying."
   218→  exit 1
   219→fi
   220→
   221→if [ "$WARN" -gt 0 ]; then
   222→  echo ""
   223→  echo "Deploy gate PASSED with warnings — review WARN items."
   224→  exit 0
   225→fi
   226→
   227→echo ""
   228→echo "Deploy gate PASSED — all checks green."
   229→exit 0
   230→

    13→OUTPUT_DIR="/thesis/output"
    14→
    15→for arg in "$@"; do
    16→  case $arg in
    17→    --watermark) WATERMARK=true ;;
    18→  esac
    19→done
    20→
    21→mkdir -p "$OUTPUT_DIR"
    22→
    23→# Copy source files to /tmp for read-only filesystem compatibility
    24→cp /thesis/*.tex /thesis/*.cls /thesis/*.bst /tmp/ 2>/dev/null || true
    25→cp /thesis/*.bib /tmp/ 2>/dev/null || true
    26→cp -r /thesis/logo /tmp/logo 2>/dev/null || true
    27→cp -r /thesis/chapters /tmp/chapters 2>/dev/null || true
    28→
    29→# Create empty .bib if not present (for compilation without references)
    30→if [ ! -f /tmp/references.bib ]; then
    31→  touch /tmp/references.bib
    32→fi
    33→
    34→cd /tmp
    35→
    36→echo "=== Pass 1: pdflatex ==="

    38→
    39→echo "=== Pass 2: bibtex ==="
    40→timeout "$TIMEOUT" bibtex main || true
    41→
    42→echo "=== Pass 3: pdflatex ==="

    44→
    45→echo "=== Pass 4: pdflatex ==="

    48→# Check if PDF was generated

Perfect! Now I have comprehensive information. Let me create a detailed summary document:

## Comprehensive Deployment Infrastructure Summary

Based on my analysis of the Apollo codebase, here's how production deployment is architected:

---

## **1. ARCHITECTURE OVERVIEW**

Apollo runs on a **single Hetzner VPS** (CX23: 2 vCPU, 4GB RAM, 40GB NVMe, ~$4/month) managed by **Coolify**. All compute is co-located on this VPS via Docker containers orchestrated by `docker-compose`. External services (Supabase, Cloudflare R2, Inngest) are stateless from the VPS's perspective.

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────┐
│   CLIENT: Next.js 15 Web App (PWA)      │
└──────────────────┬──────────────────────┘
                   │ REST + SSE
     ┌─────────────┴─────────────┐
     │  HETZNER CX23 VPS         │
     │  ─────────────────────    │
     │  ┌───────────────────┐    │
     │  │  Next.js 3000     │    │
     │  │  (Inngest worker) │    │
     │  └────────┬──────────┘    │
     │           │               │
     │  ┌────────┴────────┬──────┴──────┐
     │  │                 │              │
     │  ▼                 ▼              ▼
     │┌────────────┐┌───────────┐┌───────────┐
     ││LaTeX       ││R Plumber  ││Nginx      │
     ││(Docker)    ││(Docker)   ││Proxy      │
     ││Port: N/A   ││Port: 8787 ││443/80     │
     │└────────────┘└───────────┘└───────────┘
     │
     └─ docker-compose + Coolify
        ├─ Deployed from GitHub (git push)
        ├─ SSL via Let's Encrypt
        └─ Health checks on all services
     
     EXTERNAL (stateless):
     ├─ Supabase (DB + Auth + Realtime)
     ├─ Cloudflare R2 (file storage + CDN)
     └─ Inngest (workflow orchestration)
```

---

## **2. NEXT.JS → DOCKER INTEGRATION: LaTeX Compilation**

### **Data Flow:**

1. **Client Request**: User clicks "Compile" in the thesis editor
2. **API Route**: `POST /api/projects/[id]/compile` (Next.js App Router)
3. **Ephemeral Docker Container**: The route shells out to `docker run --rm apollo-latex`

### **Code: `/apps/web/lib/latex/compile.ts`**

The `compileTex()` function has three modes: **mock**, **docker**, **local**

**Docker Mode** (production):
```typescript
const args = [
  "run", "--rm",
  "--network=none",              // No network access
  "--read-only",                 // Read-only filesystem
  "--tmpfs", "/tmp:rw,size=512m", // 512MB temp space
  "--memory=1g",                 // 1GB memory limit
  "--pids-limit=256",            // Process limit
  "--security-opt", "no-new-privileges:true",
  "--cap-drop=ALL",              // Drop all capabilities
  "--cap-add=DAC_OVERRIDE",      // Only essential caps
  "--cap-add=FOWNER",
  "-v", `${workDir}:/thesis`,    // Mount work directory (read-write)
  containerName,
];

// Optional: custom seccomp profile (Linux only)
if (seccompExists) {
  args.push("--security-opt", `seccomp=${seccompPath}`);
}

// Execute
const { stdout, stderr } = await execFileAsync("docker", args, {
  timeout: 120_000, // 2-minute timeout
});
```

**Key Points:**
- No network access to prevent exfiltration
- Read-only filesystem (except /tmp) prevents persistence
- Compiled PDFs are persisted to `os.tmpdir()/apollo-pdfs/{projectId}.pdf`
- PDFs are then uploaded to Cloudflare R2 via `uploadToR2(r2Key, pdfBytes, "application/pdf")`
- Compilation is **admission-controlled** via a semaphore (max 1 concurrent compile)

**Dockerfile: `/docker/Dockerfile.latex`**
```dockerfile
FROM texlive/texlive:latest-minimal

# Install scheme-small + extra packages (natbib, titlesec, etc.)
RUN tlmgr install scheme-small && tlmgr install \
    natbib titlesec tocloft enumitem doi draftwatermark \
    needspace lastpage hyphenat datetime fmtcount ... && rm -rf /tmp/*

# Install Ghostscript (watermarking) + pandoc (DOCX export)
RUN apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends ghostscript pandoc

# Symlink TeX Live binaries to PATH
RUN for f in /usr/local/texlive/2025/bin/*/*; do ln -sf "$f" /usr/local/bin/; done

WORKDIR /thesis
ENTRYPOINT ["/usr/local/bin/compile.sh"]
```

**Compilation Script: `/docker/compile.sh`**
```bash
# 4-pass compilation cycle:
# 1. pdflatex (first pass)
# 2. bibtex (bibliography)
# 3. pdflatex (cross-references)
# 4. pdflatex (final numbering)

timeout 120 pdflatex -interaction=nonstopmode main.tex
timeout 120 bibtex main
timeout 120 pdflatex -interaction=nonstopmode main.tex
timeout 120 pdflatex -interaction=nonstopmode main.tex

# Apply watermark for sandbox projects (via Ghostscript)
if [ "$WATERMARK" = true ]; then
  /usr/local/bin/watermark.sh /tmp/main.pdf /tmp/main-watermarked.pdf
fi

cp /tmp/main.pdf "$OUTPUT_DIR/main.pdf"
```

---

## **3. NEXT.JS → DOCKER INTEGRATION: R Plumber Statistical Analysis**

### **Data Flow:**

1. **Client Request**: User selects analysis type (descriptive, t-test, ROC, etc.)
2. **API Route**: `POST /api/projects/[id]/analyses` → invokes Inngest workflow
3. **Inngest Worker**: Dequeues job → calls `executeAnalysis(analysisId)`
4. **HTTP to R Plumber**: `callRPlumber(endpoint, body, timeoutMs)` on `http://localhost:8787`

const R_PLUMBER_URL = process.env.R_PLUMBER_URL ?? "http://localhost:8787";

export async function callRPlumber<T>(
  endpoint: string,
  body: Record<string, unknown>,
  timeoutMs: number
): Promise<RPlumberResult<T>> {
  const url = `${R_PLUMBER_URL}${endpoint}`;
  const controller = new AbortController();
  const timer = setTimeout(() => controller.abort(), timeoutMs);

  try {
    const headers = {
      "Content-Type": "application/json",
    };
    if (process.env.R_PLUMBER_SECRET) {
      headers["Authorization"] = `Bearer ${process.env.R_PLUMBER_SECRET}`;
    }

    const response = await fetch(url, {
      method: "POST",
      headers,
      body: JSON.stringify(body),
      signal: controller.signal,
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new RPlumberError(`R Plumber ${response.status}: ${text}`);
    }

    const result = await response.json();
    if (result.error) {
      throw new RPlumberError(`R analysis error: ${result.error}`);
    }

    return { data: result as T, warnings: result.warnings ?? [] };
  } catch (err) {
    if (err instanceof DOMException && err.name === "AbortError") {
      throw new RPlumberError(`Timeout after ${timeoutMs}ms`);
    }
    throw err;
  }
}

export async function checkRPlumberHealth(): Promise<boolean> {
  try {
    const response = await fetch(`${R_PLUMBER_URL}/health`, {
      signal: AbortSignal.timeout(5000),
    });
    return response.ok;
  } catch {
    return false;
  }
}
```

```typescript
export async function runAnalysis(
  analysis: Analysis,
  datasetRows: Record<string, unknown>[]
): Promise<AnalysisResult> {
  const analysisType = analysis.analysis_type as AnalysisType;
  const endpoint = ENDPOINT_MAP[analysisType]; // e.g., "/descriptive"
  const timeout = ANALYSIS_TIMEOUTS[analysisType] ?? 30_000;
  const params = analysis.parameters_json;

  // Pre-flight validation
  if (datasetRows.length === 0) {
    throw new Error("Dataset has no rows");
  }
  
  const requiredParams = REQUIRED_PARAMS[analysisType] ?? [];
  const missingParams = requiredParams.filter(
    (key) => !params[key] || params[key].trim() === ""
  );
  if (missingParams.length > 0) {
    throw new Error(`Missing parameters: ${missingParams.join(", ")}`);
  }

  // Build request body
  const requestBody = {
    data: datasetRows,
    confidence_level: params.confidence_level ?? 0.95,
    // Only include non-empty parameters
    outcome: params.outcome,
    predictor: params.predictor,
    // ... etc.
  };

  // Call R Plumber with Sentry tracing
  const { data: rResult } = await Sentry.startSpan(
    {
      name: `r-plumber.${analysisType}`,
      op: "r.analysis",
      attributes: {
        "analysis.type": analysisType,
        "analysis.timeout_ms": timeout,
      },
    },
    () => callRPlumber<RAnalysisResponse>(endpoint, requestBody, timeout)
  );

  // Process figures: decode base64 → upload to R2 + local disk
  const figureUrls: string[] = [];
  for (const fig of rResult.figures ?? []) {
    const figureUrl = `figures/${analysis.project_id}/${analysis.id}/${fig.filename}`;
    const buffer = Buffer.from(fig.base64, "base64");

    // Upload to R2 for persistent storage
    await uploadToR2(
      `projects/${analysis.project_id}/figures/${analysis.id}/${fig.filename}`,
      buffer,
      fig.filename.endsWith(".pdf") ? "application/pdf" : "image/png"
    );

    // Also write to local disk as fallback
    const figDir = path.join(FIGURES_BASE_DIR, analysis.project_id, analysis.id);
    await mkdir(figDir, { recursive: true });
    await writeFile(path.join(figDir, fig.filename), buffer);

    // Insert figure record in database
    await supabase.from("figures").insert({
      project_id: analysis.project_id,
      figure_type: analysisType,
      source_tool: "ggplot2",
      file_url: figureUrl,
      // ...
    });
  }

  return {
    results_json: { summary: rResult.summary, table_latex: rResult.table_latex },
    figures_urls: figureUrls,
    r_script: rResult.r_script,
    warnings: rResult.warnings,
  };
}
```

const R_PLUMBER_URL = process.env.R_PLUMBER_URL ?? "http://localhost:8787";

export async function callRPlumber<T>(
  endpoint: string,
  body: Record<string, unknown>,
  timeoutMs: number
): Promise<RPlumberResult<T>> {
  const url = `${R_PLUMBER_URL}${endpoint}`;
  const controller = new AbortController();
  const timer = setTimeout(() => controller.abort(), timeoutMs);

  try {
    const headers = {
      "Content-Type": "application/json",
    };
    if (process.env.R_PLUMBER_SECRET) {
      headers["Authorization"] = `Bearer ${process.env.R_PLUMBER_SECRET}`;
    }

    const response = await fetch(url, {
      method: "POST",
      headers,
      body: JSON.stringify(body),
      signal: controller.signal,
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new RPlumberError(`R Plumber ${response.status}: ${text}`);
    }

    const result = await response.json();
    if (result.error) {
      throw new RPlumberError(`R analysis error: ${result.error}`);
    }

    return { data: result as T, warnings: result.warnings ?? [] };
  } catch (err) {
    if (err instanceof DOMException && err.name === "AbortError") {
      throw new RPlumberError(`Timeout after ${timeoutMs}ms`);
    }
    throw err;
  }
}

export async function checkRPlumberHealth(): Promise<boolean> {
  try {
    const response = await fetch(`${R_PLUMBER_URL}/health`, {
      signal: AbortSignal.timeout(5000),
    });
    return response.ok;
  } catch {
    return false;
  }
}

```typescript
export async function runAnalysis(
  analysis: Analysis,
  datasetRows: Record<string, unknown>[]
): Promise<AnalysisResult> {
  const analysisType = analysis.analysis_type as AnalysisType;
  const endpoint = ENDPOINT_MAP[analysisType]; // e.g., "/descriptive"
  const timeout = ANALYSIS_TIMEOUTS[analysisType] ?? 30_000;
  const params = analysis.parameters_json;

  // Pre-flight validation
  if (datasetRows.length === 0) {
    throw new Error("Dataset has no rows");
  }
  
  const requiredParams = REQUIRED_PARAMS[analysisType] ?? [];
  const missingParams = requiredParams.filter(
    (key) => !params[key] || params[key].trim() === ""
  );
  if (missingParams.length > 0) {
    throw new Error(`Missing parameters: ${missingParams.join(", ")}`);
  }

  // Build request body
  const requestBody = {
    data: datasetRows,
    confidence_level: params.confidence_level ?? 0.95,
    // Only include non-empty parameters
    outcome: params.outcome,
    predictor: params.predictor,
    // ... etc.
  };

  // Call R Plumber with Sentry tracing
  const { data: rResult } = await Sentry.startSpan(
    {
      name: `r-plumber.${analysisType}`,
      op: "r.analysis",
      attributes: {
        "analysis.type": analysisType,
        "analysis.timeout_ms": timeout,
      },
    },
    () => callRPlumber<RAnalysisResponse>(endpoint, requestBody, timeout)
  );

  // Process figures: decode base64 → upload to R2 + local disk
  const figureUrls: string[] = [];
  for (const fig of rResult.figures ?? []) {
    const figureUrl = `figures/${analysis.project_id}/${analysis.id}/${fig.filename}`;
    const buffer = Buffer.from(fig.base64, "base64");

    // Upload to R2 for persistent storage
    await uploadToR2(
      `projects/${analysis.project_id}/figures/${analysis.id}/${fig.filename}`,
      buffer,
      fig.filename.endsWith(".pdf") ? "application/pdf" : "image/png"
    );

    // Also write to local disk as fallback
    const figDir = path.join(FIGURES_BASE_DIR, analysis.project_id, analysis.id);
    await mkdir(figDir, { recursive: true });
    await writeFile(path.join(figDir, fig.filename), buffer);

    // Insert figure record in database
    await supabase.from("figures").insert({
      project_id: analysis.project_id,
      figure_type: analysisType,
      source_tool: "ggplot2",
      file_url: figureUrl,
      // ...
    });
  }

  return {
    results_json: { summary: rResult.summary, table_latex: rResult.table_latex },
    figures_urls: figureUrls,
    r_script: rResult.r_script,
    warnings: rResult.warnings,
  };
}
```

## 1. Updating CLS files, templates, etc.

**Short answer: You just update the files on disk. No Docker rebuild needed.**

Here's why — look at what `compile.ts` actually does (lines 113-131):

```
compile.ts reads CLS from host disk:    templates/sskm-thesis.cls
                                              ↓
copies into a temp folder:               /tmp/apollo-compile-{projectId}/sskm-thesis.cls
                                              ↓
mounts that folder into container:       docker run -v /tmp/apollo-compile-xyz:/thesis
                                              ↓
compile.sh copies to /tmp inside:        cp /thesis/*.cls /tmp/
```

The Docker image itself does **not** contain your CLS files. `compile.ts` reads them fresh from the host's `templates/` directory every single compilation. So:

- **Update a CLS file**: Push to git → Coolify pulls → next compile uses the new version. Zero downtime.
- **Add a new CLS file**: Same — just add it to `templates/`, wire it in the code.
- **Update compile.sh or watermark.sh**: These ARE baked into the image (`COPY docker/compile.sh`), so this requires a `docker build` + restart. But Coolify handles that automatically on git push.
- **Add new TeX packages** (like `mathrsfs`): Requires editing `Dockerfile.latex` → rebuild. Again, Coolify handles it.

**What to watch for**: The compose service mounts `../templates:/templates:ro` but that's for the sleeping container, which we established is dead code for compilation. The ephemeral `docker run` does NOT mount templates — `compile.ts` copies them into the workDir. This is actually a good thing: each compile gets a clean, isolated copy.

---

## 2. Whitelist vs Blacklist Seccomp — Honest Assessment

**What we implemented**: Whitelist (deny-by-default).

```json
"defaultAction": "SCMP_ACT_ERRNO"   ← block everything
"syscalls": [{ "names": [...], "action": "SCMP_ACT_ALLOW" }]  ← allow only these
```

**The alternative** (Docker's built-in default): Blacklist — allow everything, block ~44 known-dangerous syscalls.

| | Whitelist (what we did) | Blacklist (Docker default) |
|---|---|---|
| **Security** | Stronger — unknown/new syscalls blocked | Weaker — only known-bad ones blocked |
| **Reliability** | Riskier — missing syscall = SIGSYS crash | Safer — things just work |
| **Maintenance** | Higher — kernel updates may add new syscalls your programs need | Zero — Docker updates the default list |
| **Debugging** | Harder — "why did pdflatex crash?" requires `dmesg \| grep seccomp` | Trivial — it almost never causes issues |

**My honest recommendation**: For your situation — a single-developer project where reliability matters more than defending against nation-state actors — **the blacklist (Docker default) is objectively the better choice**. Here's why:

1. Your containers already have `--network=none`, `--read-only`, `--cap-drop=ALL`, `--memory=1g`, `--pids-limit=256`. That's already very strong.
2. The whitelist adds marginal security on top of those defences, but introduces a real failure mode: if TeX Live updates and calls a new syscall, compilations silently fail with a cryptic SIGSYS.
3. You'd be the one debugging it at 2am.

**What we actually shipped**: The whitelist profiles exist as files, but `compile.ts` has a **graceful fallback** — if the profile file isn't found or you're on macOS, Docker's default blacklist applies:

```typescript
let seccompExists = false;
try {
  await access(seccompPath);
  seccompExists = true;
} catch {
  // Docker's default seccomp applies (still secure)
}
```

So you have a choice:
- **Leave as-is**: Profiles exist, get used on VPS if present, fall back to Docker default if not. Best of both worlds.
- **Remove the profiles entirely**: Delete the two JSON files, the fallback means nothing changes. You still have all the other protections.
- **Keep profiles but test on VPS first**: Run `deploy-conformance.sh` which does a test compile with the profile. If it passes, you're good.

---

## 3. Is the security hardening worth the debugging cost?

Let me break this into tiers:

### Tier 1: FREE — zero debugging cost, always keep these

| Flag | What it does | Why it matters |
|---|---|---|
| `--network=none` | Container can't talk to the internet | LaTeX is Turing-complete. `\write18` can execute shell commands. Without this, a malicious `.tex` file could `curl` your API keys out. |
| `--read-only` + `--tmpfs` | Can't write to disk permanently | Even if code executes, it dies with the container |
| `--memory=1g` | Hard memory cap | Prevents a runaway compile from OOM-killing your Next.js app |
| `--pids-limit=256` | Prevents fork bombs | A `\write18{:(){ :\|:& };:}` can't bring down the VPS |
| `no-new-privileges` | Can't escalate via setuid | One line, zero risk of breaking anything |

**These flags have NEVER caused a debugging issue in any Docker deployment I'm aware of. Always keep them.**

### Tier 2: LOW COST — rarely causes issues

| Flag | What it does | Debugging cost |
|---|---|---|
| `--cap-drop=ALL` + selective `--cap-add` | Only allows file ownership operations | Might fail if a TeX package tries something exotic (never seen it happen with pdflatex) |

### Tier 3: MEDIUM COST — the seccomp profiles

This is the only part that could bite you. The question is: **what's the actual threat?**

Your LaTeX container:
- Receives AI-generated content (Claude writes the LaTeX)
- Has no network access (can't exfiltrate anything)
- Has no access to API keys, database, or user files
- Dies after compilation (ephemeral `--rm`)

Your R Plumber container:
- Receives **structured JSON parameters**, NOT arbitrary R code
- Endpoints are parameterised (`/descriptive`, `/t-test`, etc.)
- Has a shared secret for auth
- Only talks to localhost

**The realistic attack scenario**: Someone crafts a malicious synopsis that tricks Claude into generating LaTeX with `\write18{malicious command}`. But `\write18` is disabled by `-interaction=nonstopmode` + default TeX Live config, and even if it weren't, `--network=none` means nothing can leave the container.

**Bottom line**: The Tier 1 flags (network, read-only, memory, pids) give you 95% of the security value at 0% debugging cost. The seccomp profiles give you the remaining 5% at maybe 20% of the debugging cost. The graceful fallback means you can deploy without them and add them later after VPS testing.

---

## 4. Production Infrastructure Flow

Here's the complete picture:

```
STUDENT'S BROWSER
       │
       │ HTTPS (port 443)
       ▼
┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  HETZNER CX23 VPS  (2 vCPU, 4GB RAM, 40GB NVMe, ~$4/mo)       │
│                                                                  │
│  ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐     │
│  │  COOLIFY (manages everything)                           │     │
│  │  - Git-push deploy (GitHub webhook)                     │     │
│  │  - SSL via Let's Encrypt (auto-renew)                   │     │
│  │  - Nginx reverse proxy (443 → 3000)                     │     │
│  │  - Environment variables (secrets stored here)          │     │
│  └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘     │
│                                                                  │
│  ┌──────────────────────┐                                        │
│  │  NEXT.JS (port 3000) │ ← The brain. Handles everything.      │
│  │  - API routes         │                                       │
│  │  - SSR pages          │                                       │
│  │  - Inngest worker     │                                       │
│  └──────┬───────┬───────┘                                        │
│         │       │                                                │
│    ┌────┘       └────┐                                           │
│    ▼                 ▼                                            │
│  ┌─────────┐  ┌──────────┐                                       │
│  │ LaTeX   │  │ R Plumber│                                       │
│  │ (Docker)│  │ (Docker) │                                       │
│  │ No net  │  │ port 8787│                                       │
│  │ Ephemeral│ │ Persistent│                                      │
│  └─────────┘  └──────────┘                                       │
└──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
       │                    │                    │
       ▼                    ▼                    ▼
   SUPABASE            CLOUDFLARE R2         ANTHROPIC
   (DB + Auth)         (PDF/figure           (Claude API
   Free tier           storage)              for AI gen)
   PostgreSQL +        Signed URLs           SSE streaming
   RLS policies        Free 10GB             Sonnet/Opus
```

### The actual request flow for a compile:

```
1. Student clicks "Compile" in browser
2. POST /api/projects/{id}/compile → Next.js API route
3. API route calls compileTex() in compile.ts
4. compile.ts:
   a. Creates temp dir: /tmp/apollo-compile-{projectId}/
   b. Reads CLS, BST, logos from templates/ on host disk
   c. Writes main.tex, chapters, references.bib into temp dir
   d. Runs: docker run --rm --network=none ... -v /tmp/...:/thesis apollo-latex
   e. compile.sh inside container:
      - Copies files to /tmp (read-only filesystem workaround)
      - pdflatex → bibtex → pdflatex → pdflatex (4-pass)
      - Outputs PDF to /thesis/output/main.pdf
   f. compile.ts reads the PDF from temp dir
   g. Uploads PDF to Cloudflare R2
   h. Cleans up temp dir
5. Returns signed R2 URL to browser
6. Browser renders PDF via react-pdf
```

### The actual request flow for R analysis:

```
1. Student configures analysis (select type, variables, etc.)
2. POST /api/projects/{id}/analyses → Next.js API route
3. Route creates analysis record in Supabase, fires Inngest event
4. Inngest worker picks up the job
5. Worker calls callRPlumber("/descriptive", {data, params}, 15000)
6. HTTP POST to http://localhost:8787/descriptive (inside VPS)
7. R Plumber:
   - Validates Bearer token
   - Runs gtsummary/ggplot2/survival analysis
   - Returns JSON: {summary, table_latex, figures: [{filename, base64}]}
8. Worker:
   - Decodes base64 figures → uploads to R2
   - Saves results + table_latex to Supabase
9. Student sees results in UI (Supabase Realtime pushes update)
```

### Hiccups already accounted for:

| Hiccup | How it's handled |
|--------|-----------------|
| **Compile takes too long** | 120s timeout on `execFileAsync`, 120s timeout inside `compile.sh` per pass |
| **R analysis timeout** | Per-type timeouts (15s descriptive, 60s meta-analysis), `AbortSignal.timeout()` |
| **Docker not available** | `getCompileMode()` falls back to `mock` mode; health check reports `degraded` |
| **R Plumber down** | Health check detects it; Inngest retries failed jobs |
| **Memory exhaustion** | `--memory=1g` on LaTeX, `512m` on R — containers get OOM-killed, not the VPS |
| **Concurrent compile contention** | Admission control semaphore (max 1 concurrent compile) |
| **CLS file missing** | `try/catch` in compile.ts — silently continues (compilation will fail with clear LaTeX error) |
| **PDF not generated** | `compile.ts` checks `pdfPath !== null` before declaring success |
| **AI generates bad LaTeX** | Pre-flight validation blocks on errors; AI validation (non-blocking) warns |
| **Unicode in BibTeX** | `normaliseUnicode()` converts all non-ASCII to LaTeX commands |
| **Bare `&` in journal names** | `escapeBareAmpersands()` escapes outside tabular environments |
| **Fork bomb via \write18** | `--pids-limit=256` + `-interaction=nonstopmode` disables \write18 |
| **SSL cert expiry** | `deploy-conformance.sh` check #10 warns at 14 days |
| **Secret leak to containers** | Deploy conformance check #9 scans container env vars |
| **VPS dies completely** | Stateless architecture — provision new CX23, `git clone`, Coolify deploys. DB is on Supabase (external), files on R2 (external). Recovery: ~30 minutes. |

### What's NOT yet accounted for (future work):

- **Horizontal scaling**: Currently 1 VPS. If you need >1 concurrent compile, you'd need a second VPS or a queue.
- **CSP headers**: Deferred to avoid breaking Clerk/Sentry/shadcn inline styles. Needs careful testing.
- **Rate limiting on AI endpoints**: Currently relies on Anthropic's own rate limits. Should add per-user throttling.
- **Backup automation**: R2 backup to Hetzner Storage Box is documented but not automated yet.

   681→## J. Modified Option C — LaTeX Editor Architecture (Reference)
   682→
   683→As discussed in Part II, the recommended solution to the LaTeX round-trip problem:
   684→
   685→**Current**: AI -> LaTeX -> `latexToTiptap()` (lossy) -> Rich editor -> `tiptapToLatex()` (lossy) -> Compile
   686→**Proposed**: AI -> LaTeX -> CodeMirror 6 (canonical) -> Compile
   687→
   688→### Key Architecture Points
   689→1. **CodeMirror 6** as primary editor (already used for source view)
   690→2. **Syntax decorations**: LaTeX commands rendered in muted colour/different font — visually distinct but editable
   691→3. **Atomic ranges**: Structural commands (`\section{}`, `\begin{}`/`\end{}`) protected via transaction filters
   692→4. **Toolbar**: WYSIWYG shortcuts (Bold -> wraps in `\textbf{}`, Italic -> `\textit{}`, etc.)
   693→5. **Citation chips**: `\cite{key}` rendered as inline badges showing author/year
   694→6. **Math preview**: Inline math (`$...$`) gets a tooltip/popup with rendered MathJax
   695→7. **Fold markers**: Complex environments (`tabular`, `figure`) can be folded to single-line summaries
   696→8. **DB schema change**: `latex_content` becomes canonical; `rich_content_json` deprecated
   697→9. **Eliminates**: `latexToTiptap()`, `tiptapToLatex()`, Novel/Tiptap dependency
   698→10. **Keeps**: `sanitiseChapterLatex()`, `escapeBareAmpersands()`, `normaliseUnicode()` for compile-time safety

   743→## Executive Summary

Five parallel agents audited every API route, every migration file, every payment flow, every third-party data transfer, and the full infrastructure reliability surface.

   754→
   755→## IV-A: Authentication & Security Posture
   756→
   757→### A1. Middleware Route Protection
   758→
   759→**File**: `middleware.ts` (lines 4-12)
   760→
   761→Protected routes: `/dashboard(.*)`, `/projects(.*)`, `/licences(.*)`, `/checkout(.*)`, `/api/projects(.*)`, `/api/licenses(.*)`, `/api/upload(.*)`.
   762→
   763→**Missing from middleware**: `/api/checkout(.*)`, `/api/synopsis(.*)`, `/api/citations(.*)`, `/api/inngest(.*)`. All have application-level auth (`getAuthenticatedUser()`), but middleware should be the authoritative gate.
   764→
   765→**Severity: MEDIUM**
   766→
   767→### A2. IDOR Vulnerabilities (Insecure Direct Object Reference)
   768→
   769→| Route | File | Client | Ownership Check | Severity |
   770→|-------|------|--------|----------------|----------|
   771→| `GET /api/projects/[id]` | `app/api/projects/[id]/route.ts:23` | Server (RLS) | NO explicit `user_id` | CRITICAL |
   772→| `PATCH /api/projects/[id]` | `app/api/projects/[id]/route.ts:60` | Server (RLS) | NO explicit `user_id` | CRITICAL |
   773→| `DELETE /api/projects/[id]` | `app/api/projects/[id]/route.ts:89` | Server (RLS) | NO explicit `user_id` | CRITICAL |
   774→| `GET /api/projects` | `app/api/projects/route.ts:16` | Server (RLS) | NO `user_id` filter | MEDIUM |
   775→| `GET /api/licenses` | `app/api/licenses/route.ts:11` | Server (RLS) | NO `user_id` filter | MEDIUM |
   776→| `GET /api/projects/[id]/share` | `app/api/projects/[id]/share/route.ts:79` | Admin (bypasses RLS) | NO ownership check | CRITICAL |
   777→| `POST /api/upload/signed-url` | `app/api/upload/signed-url/route.ts:20` | N/A (R2 direct) | NO project ownership | HIGH |
   778→
   779→The first 5 routes use `createServerSupabaseClient()` with RLS, so database-level policies provide protection. But this is defence-in-depth violation --- if RLS misconfigures or the Clerk-Supabase JWT integration fails, all projects are exposed.
   780→
   781→The share GET and upload routes are **genuinely vulnerable**: they use the admin client (bypasses RLS) with no ownership check.
   782→
   783→### A3. Role Escalation via Direct Supabase Client
   784→
   785→**File**: `supabase/migrations/002_create_users.sql` (lines 24-28)
   786→
   787→The `users` UPDATE RLS policy allows unrestricted updates to the user's own row, including the `role` field. The browser-side Supabase anon key is exposed via `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY`. A malicious user could set their own `role` to `admin` via a direct Supabase update call, gaining organisation-wide data views.
   788→
   789→**Severity: HIGH**
   790→
   791→**Fix**: Restrict the UPDATE policy:
   792→```sql
   793→WITH CHECK (
   794→  clerk_user_id = (select auth.jwt()->>'sub')
   795→  AND role = OLD.role  -- prevent role changes
   796→);
   797→```
   798→
   799→### A4. Input Validation & Injection
   800→
   801→- **SQL Injection**: No vectors found. All queries use Supabase parameterised builder. **GOOD.**
   802→- **Command Injection**: `execFile` (not `exec`) used for Docker --- prevents shell metacharacter injection. **GOOD.**
   803→- **XSS**: `dangerouslySetInnerHTML` in `title-page-preview.tsx` without sanitisation. **MEDIUM.**
   804→- **LaTeX Injection**: Thorough escape pipeline (`escapeLatex`, `normaliseUnicode`, `escapeBareAmpersands`). **GOOD.**
   805→- **Header Injection**: `Content-Disposition` in DOCX export interpolates `project.title` without encoding. **LOW.**
   806→
   807→### A5. CSRF Protection
   808→
   809→No explicit CSRF middleware or tokens. Clerk manages session cookies with `SameSite=Lax` by default, which mitigates CSRF for state-changing POST requests. No additional action required for now.

   811→### A6. Rate Limiting
   812→
   813→**File**: `lib/ai/rate-limit.ts`
   814→
   815→In-memory `Map` with 10 requests/hour/user. Issues:
   816→- Resets on server restart/deploy
   817→- Not shared across instances
   818→- Only applied to the generate route --- NOT applied to: refine, auto-detect, synopsis parse, citation search, compile

   821→
   822→### A7. File Upload Security
   823→
   824→- **Type validation**: PDF, CSV, XLSX, PNG, JPEG --- validated in R2 client and route. **GOOD.**
   825→- **Path traversal**: Rejects `..`, `//`, `\\` + sanitises to `[^\w.\-]` -> `_`. **GOOD.**
   826→- **File size not enforced on signed URL**: `MAX_FILE_SIZE` (50MB) defined but never passed as `ContentLength` constraint. **MEDIUM.**

   851→## IV-B: Payment & Licence Pipeline
   852→
   853→### B1. Payment Flow Architecture
   854→
   855→1. Checkout UI -> `POST /api/checkout` -> Razorpay order (INR) or Stripe session (USD)
   856→2. Payment gateway completes
   857→3. Webhook fires -> signature verified -> idempotency checked -> licence provisioned
   858→
   859→### B2. Critical: Webhook Race Condition (Double Provisioning)
   860→
   861→**Files**: `app/api/webhooks/razorpay/route.ts:62-63`, `app/api/webhooks/stripe/route.ts:62-63`
   862→
   863→```typescript
   864→await provisionLicence(userId, planType, projectId);
   865→await markEventProcessed("razorpay", eventId, eventType);
   866→```
   867→
   868→If `provisionLicence` succeeds but `markEventProcessed` fails (DB write error), the next webhook retry provisions a **second licence**. Not atomic --- no transaction wrapping.
   869→
   870→**Severity: CRITICAL**
   871→
   872→**Fix**: Use `INSERT ... ON CONFLICT DO NOTHING RETURNING id` as the first step. If no row returned, event was already processed.
   873→
   874→### B3. Professional Plan: 1 Licence Instead of 3
   875→
   876→Landing page and checkout UI advertise "3 thesis licences" for Professional plan. `provisionLicence()` always inserts exactly ONE licence row.
   877→
   878→**Severity: HIGH (commercial promise not fulfilled)**
   879→
   880→### B4. No Licence Expiry Enforcement
   881→
   882→`expires_at` is set at provisioning (30 days for monthly, 1 year for one-time), but **no cron job, middleware, or API check** verifies whether a licence has expired. Monthly subscribers get perpetual access.
   883→
   884→**Severity: HIGH**
   885→
   886→### B5. Missing Licence Gates

## Executive Summary

## A. AI Integration Pipeline

### A1. Prompt Architecture (`lib/ai/prompts.ts`)

**Strengths**:
- Each of 12 phases has a detailed structural template with numbered subsections
- Citation handling via `---BIBTEX---` separator is explicit and consistent
- British English enforced at multiple layers (COMMON_RULES rule #1, synopsis parser, review, QC)
- Word count targets per prompt with hard limits (e.g., Introduction: 700-1,200 words, hard limit 1,380)
- Medical domain specificity: NBEMS 12-section M&M, ICMR 2017, STROBE/CONSORT, PICO format

**Issues Found**:

| # | Issue | Severity | Details |
|---|-------|----------|---------|
| A1 | **Phase 9 (References) prompt missing** | P1 | `getPhaseSystemPrompt()` has no `case 9`. The references phase is either handled entirely by BibTeX aggregation or simply skipped. There should be a prompt that consolidates and validates all BibTeX entries. |
| A2 | **Phase 6a/6b conflated** | P1 | PLAN specifies Phase 6a (Dataset) and 6b (Results) as separate sub-phases. `getPhaseSystemPrompt(6)` returns only `RESULTS_SYSTEM_PROMPT`. Dataset generation uses a separate prompt via a different API route, not the phase pipeline. Phase numbering is inconsistent with PLAN. |
| A3 | **Previous section context truncated to 3,000 chars** | P0 | In `getPhaseUserMessage()`: `.map((s) => s.content.slice(0, 3000))`. For ROL (3,500-4,500 words / ~20,000+ chars), only the first ~500 words are passed as context. The Discussion chapter — which must compare findings with literature — receives almost no ROL context. |
| A4 | **No Unicode avoidance in COMMON_RULES** | P1 | Despite Unicode being documented as a critical BibTeX-breaking issue in MEMORY.md, COMMON_RULES never tells the AI to avoid Unicode characters. Escaping happens downstream in `escape.ts`, but prevention at source would reduce failures. |
| A5 | **Word count targets disagree across 3 files** | P0 | `prompts.ts`, `word-count-targets.ts`, and `final-qc.ts` all specify different ranges for the same phases. Example: Introduction is 700-1,200 (prompt), 750-1,200 (word-count-targets), 500-750 (final-qc). A section could pass mid-pipeline review but fail final QC. |
| A6 | **Synopsis parse prompt duplicated with different schemas** | P2 | `SYNOPSIS_PARSE_SYSTEM_PROMPT` in prompts.ts extracts one field set; `/api/synopsis/parse` uses a completely different inline prompt extracting different fields. |

## B. Citation Pipeline

### B1. Resolution Engine (`lib/citations/resolve.ts`, `auto-resolve.ts`)

| # | Issue | Severity | Details |
|---|-------|----------|---------|
| B1 | **Orphan cite keys without DB records bypass Tier D stripping** | P0 | If `resolveSectionCitations()` times out before creating Tier D placeholders for orphan keys, those `\cite{key}` commands persist through to compilation and produce "undefined citation" BibTeX warnings. `stripTierDCitations` only removes keys that exist in the `citations` table as Tier D. A key with NO DB record at all survives as `\cite{key}` in the chapter body. **Fix**: Also strip cite keys in `section.citation_keys[]` that have no matching record in the citations table. |
| B2 | **No retry logic for API failures** | P1 | All CrossRef/PubMed calls are one-shot with 10-second timeout. A transient network failure during generation permanently loses resolution for that batch. No exponential backoff, no retry queue, no circuit breaker. |
| B3 | **Re-resolve Strategy 2 lacks title verification** | P1 | The re-resolve route searches CrossRef by key pattern ("kumar 2023") and takes the first result with a DOI, without checking title similarity. The main `resolveEntry()` function correctly uses a 0.85 Levenshtein threshold — re-resolve should do the same. |

### B2. Pre-seeding (`lib/citations/pre-seed.ts`)

| # | Issue | Severity | Details |
|---|-------|----------|---------|
| B4 | **Pre-seeded references not persisted to DB** | P2 | Pre-seeded references are only injected into the AI prompt. If the AI uses a pre-seeded reference but doesn't include it in the `---BIBTEX---` trailer (possible if truncated by token limits), the cite key becomes a Tier D orphan or goes missing entirely. Persisting pre-seeded references upfront (as Tier A, since they came from PubMed with DOIs) would be more robust. |
| B5 | **Timeout budget mismatch for ROL** | P2 | Generation has a 15-second timeout for resolution, but ROL phase has up to 30 pre-seeded refs and potentially 30+ AI-generated refs. Each ref requires up to 3 network calls with concurrency limited to 3. This could easily exceed 15 seconds. |

## C. LaTeX Pipeline

### C1. Round-Trip Problem (`latex-to-tiptap.ts` ↔ `tiptap-to-latex.ts`)

| # | Issue | Severity | Details |
|---|-------|----------|---------|
| C1 | **Round-trip is lossy — inline math destroyed** | P0 | `escapeLatex()` escapes `$`, `\`, `{`, `}`, `^`, `_`. If math notation appears in a paragraph text node, `$p < 0.05$` becomes `\$p < 0.05\$` — literal dollar signs, not math mode. Medical theses are full of p-values and statistical notation. |
| C2 | **`\footnote{}`, `\url{}`, `\textsuperscript{}` destroyed** | P0 | These unrecognised LaTeX commands are garbled — backslash consumed as plain text in the Tiptap parser. Common in academic writing. |
| C3 | **`\label{}` stripped permanently** | P1 | Stripped in preprocessing, never restored. Cross-references break. |

**What survives cleanly**: Section headings, bold/italic/code/underline, `\cite{}`, bullet/numbered lists, blockquotes, complex environments as codeBlocks, basic paragraph text.

**Recommended solution**: Modified Option C — make LaTeX canonical, use CodeMirror 6 as primary editor with syntax-highlighted decorations and atomic ranges for structural commands. Eliminates the entire round-trip. See Part III Section J for full architectural specification.

## J. Modified Option C — LaTeX Editor Architecture (Reference)

As discussed in Part II, the recommended solution to the LaTeX round-trip problem:

**Current**: AI -> LaTeX -> `latexToTiptap()` (lossy) -> Rich editor -> `tiptapToLatex()` (lossy) -> Compile
**Proposed**: AI -> LaTeX -> CodeMirror 6 (canonical) -> Compile

### Key Architecture Points
1. **CodeMirror 6** as primary editor (already used for source view)
2. **Syntax decorations**: LaTeX commands rendered in muted colour/different font — visually distinct but editable
3. **Atomic ranges**: Structural commands (`\section{}`, `\begin{}`/`\end{}`) protected via transaction filters
4. **Toolbar**: WYSIWYG shortcuts (Bold -> wraps in `\textbf{}`, Italic -> `\textit{}`, etc.)
5. **Citation chips**: `\cite{key}` rendered as inline badges showing author/year
6. **Math preview**: Inline math (`$...$`) gets a tooltip/popup with rendered MathJax
7. **Fold markers**: Complex environments (`tabular`, `figure`) can be folded to single-line summaries
8. **DB schema change**: `latex_content` becomes canonical; `rich_content_json` deprecated
9. **Eliminates**: `latexToTiptap()`, `tiptapToLatex()`, Novel/Tiptap dependency
10. **Keeps**: `sanitiseChapterLatex()`, `escapeBareAmpersands()`, `normaliseUnicode()` for compile-time safety

## Executive Summary

Five parallel agents audited every API route, every migration file, every payment flow, every third-party data transfer, and the full infrastructure reliability surface.

## IV-A: Authentication & Security Posture

### A1. Middleware Route Protection

**File**: `middleware.ts` (lines 4-12)

Protected routes: `/dashboard(.*)`, `/projects(.*)`, `/licences(.*)`, `/checkout(.*)`, `/api/projects(.*)`, `/api/licenses(.*)`, `/api/upload(.*)`.

**Missing from middleware**: `/api/checkout(.*)`, `/api/synopsis(.*)`, `/api/citations(.*)`, `/api/inngest(.*)`. All have application-level auth (`getAuthenticatedUser()`), but middleware should be the authoritative gate.

**Severity: MEDIUM**

### A2. IDOR Vulnerabilities (Insecure Direct Object Reference)

| Route | File | Client | Ownership Check | Severity |
|-------|------|--------|----------------|----------|
| `GET /api/projects/[id]` | `app/api/projects/[id]/route.ts:23` | Server (RLS) | NO explicit `user_id` | CRITICAL |
| `PATCH /api/projects/[id]` | `app/api/projects/[id]/route.ts:60` | Server (RLS) | NO explicit `user_id` | CRITICAL |
| `DELETE /api/projects/[id]` | `app/api/projects/[id]/route.ts:89` | Server (RLS) | NO explicit `user_id` | CRITICAL |
| `GET /api/projects` | `app/api/projects/route.ts:16` | Server (RLS) | NO `user_id` filter | MEDIUM |
| `GET /api/licenses` | `app/api/licenses/route.ts:11` | Server (RLS) | NO `user_id` filter | MEDIUM |
| `GET /api/projects/[id]/share` | `app/api/projects/[id]/share/route.ts:79` | Admin (bypasses RLS) | NO ownership check | CRITICAL |
| `POST /api/upload/signed-url` | `app/api/upload/signed-url/route.ts:20` | N/A (R2 direct) | NO project ownership | HIGH |

The first 5 routes use `createServerSupabaseClient()` with RLS, so database-level policies provide protection. But this is defence-in-depth violation --- if RLS misconfigures or the Clerk-Supabase JWT integration fails, all projects are exposed.

The share GET and upload routes are **genuinely vulnerable**: they use the admin client (bypasses RLS) with no ownership check.

### A3. Role Escalation via Direct Supabase Client

**File**: `supabase/migrations/002_create_users.sql` (lines 24-28)

The `users` UPDATE RLS policy allows unrestricted updates to the user's own row, including the `role` field. The browser-side Supabase anon key is exposed via `NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY`. A malicious user could set their own `role` to `admin` via a direct Supabase update call, gaining organisation-wide data views.

**Severity: HIGH**

**Fix**: Restrict the UPDATE policy:
```sql
WITH CHECK (
  clerk_user_id = (select auth.jwt()->>'sub')
  AND role = OLD.role  -- prevent role changes
);
```

### A4. Input Validation & Injection

- **SQL Injection**: No vectors found. All queries use Supabase parameterised builder. **GOOD.**
- **Command Injection**: `execFile` (not `exec`) used for Docker --- prevents shell metacharacter injection. **GOOD.**
- **XSS**: `dangerouslySetInnerHTML` in `title-page-preview.tsx` without sanitisation. **MEDIUM.**
- **LaTeX Injection**: Thorough escape pipeline (`escapeLatex`, `normaliseUnicode`, `escapeBareAmpersands`). **GOOD.**
- **Header Injection**: `Content-Disposition` in DOCX export interpolates `project.title` without encoding. **LOW.**

### A5. CSRF Protection

No explicit CSRF middleware or tokens. Clerk manages session cookies with `SameSite=Lax` by default, which mitigates CSRF for state-changing POST requests. No additional action required for now.

### A6. Rate Limiting

**File**: `lib/ai/rate-limit.ts`

In-memory `Map` with 10 requests/hour/user. Issues:
- Resets on server restart/deploy
- Not shared across instances
- Only applied to the generate route --- NOT applied to: refine, auto-detect, synopsis parse, citation search, compile

**Severity: HIGH** --- Unlimited AI API calls via unprotected endpoints.

### A7. File Upload Security

- **Type validation**: PDF, CSV, XLSX, PNG, JPEG --- validated in R2 client and route. **GOOD.**
- **Path traversal**: Rejects `..`, `//`, `\\` + sanitises to `[^\w.\-]` -> `_`. **GOOD.**
- **File size not enforced on signed URL**: `MAX_FILE_SIZE` (50MB) defined but never passed as `ContentLength` constraint. **MEDIUM.**
- **Dataset upload no file size check**: `FormData` file read without size validation --- OOM risk. **MEDIUM.**

### A8. Docker Container Security

LaTeX container: `network_mode: none`, `read_only: true`, `mem_limit: 1g`, `pids_limit: 256`, `cap_drop: ALL` + minimal `cap_add`, `no-new-privileges: true`. **Excellent hardening.**

R Plumber container: Similar hardening but port `8787` exposed to all interfaces, `seccomp:unconfined`, and **no inter-service authentication**. Any process that can reach port 8787 can run analyses.

**Severity: MEDIUM** (R Plumber auth)

### A9. DEV_LICENCE_BYPASS

**File**: `lib/phases/transitions.ts:44`

```typescript
const devBypass = process.env.DEV_LICENCE_BYPASS === "true";
```

No `NODE_ENV` guard. If accidentally set in production, all licence requirements are bypassed.

**Severity: HIGH**

## IV-B: Payment & Licence Pipeline

### B1. Payment Flow Architecture

1. Checkout UI -> `POST /api/checkout` -> Razorpay order (INR) or Stripe session (USD)
2. Payment gateway completes
3. Webhook fires -> signature verified -> idempotency checked -> licence provisioned

### B2. Critical: Webhook Race Condition (Double Provisioning)

**Files**: `app/api/webhooks/razorpay/route.ts:62-63`, `app/api/webhooks/stripe/route.ts:62-63`

```typescript
await provisionLicence(userId, planType, projectId);
await markEventProcessed("razorpay", eventId, eventType);
```

If `provisionLicence` succeeds but `markEventProcessed` fails (DB write error), the next webhook retry provisions a **second licence**. Not atomic --- no transaction wrapping.

**Severity: CRITICAL**

**Fix**: Use `INSERT ... ON CONFLICT DO NOTHING RETURNING id` as the first step. If no row returned, event was already processed.

### B3. Professional Plan: 1 Licence Instead of 3

Landing page and checkout UI advertise "3 thesis licences" for Professional plan. `provisionLicence()` always inserts exactly ONE licence row.

**Severity: HIGH (commercial promise not fulfilled)**

### B4. No Licence Expiry Enforcement

`expires_at` is set at provisioning (30 days for monthly, 1 year for one-time), but **no cron job, middleware, or API check** verifies whether a licence has expired. Monthly subscribers get perpetual access.

**Severity: HIGH**

### B5. Missing Licence Gates

| Route | Licence Check | AI/Compute Cost | Severity |
|-------|--------------|-----------------|----------|
| `POST .../generate` | NO | Claude tokens | HIGH |
| `POST .../refine` | NO | Claude tokens | HIGH |
| `POST .../compile` | NO | Docker compute | MEDIUM |
| `POST .../auto-detect` | NO | Claude tokens | MEDIUM |
| `POST .../datasets/generate` | NO | Claude tokens | MEDIUM |
| `POST .../qc` | NO | Compute | MEDIUM |
| `GET .../preview.pdf` | NO | Bandwidth | MEDIUM |
| `POST .../share` | NO | N/A | MEDIUM |

Sandbox users can consume expensive AI tokens for phases they should not access. The only gate is at the *approval/advancement* step, not at *generation*.

### B6. No Plan-Based Feature Differentiation

Professional plan advertises "Priority compile queue", "Supervisor collaboration links", "Source LaTeX export" --- none implemented. `student_monthly` and `professional_monthly` licences grant identical access.

**Severity: HIGH**

### B7. Hidden "addon" Plan

`addon` plan (Rs 299) exists in validation schema and pricing table but is NOT displayed in checkout UI. Can be purchased via direct API call --- cheapest licence available.

**Severity: MEDIUM**

### B8. "Monthly" Plans Are One-Time Purchases

No Stripe subscription management, no recurring billing, no cancellation webhook handler, no refund endpoint. Despite being called "monthly", all payments are one-time (`mode: "payment"` in Stripe session). Combined with no expiry enforcement (B4), these are effectively perpetual one-time purchases.

**Severity: HIGH**

### B9. Pricing Inconsistency

| Source | Student | Professional |
|--------|---------|-------------|
| Landing page | Rs 2,499/month | Rs 4,999/month |
| FAQ section | Rs 2,499/month or Rs 14,999/6-month | Rs 4,999/month or Rs 24,999/lifetime |
| Actual checkout | Rs 499/month | Rs 999/month |

**Severity: MEDIUM (legal/trust risk)**

### B10. Non-Atomic Licence Attachment

`POST /api/licenses/[lid]/attach/[pid]` updates licence and project in separate calls. If licence update succeeds but project update fails, licence is consumed but project remains sandbox.

**Severity: MEDIUM**

### B11. Unlimited Project Creation

No limit on projects per user. Combined with missing licence gates (B5), a user can create unlimited sandbox projects, each with its own 1.2M token budget.

**Severity: MEDIUM**

### B12. Checkout Does Not Validate project_id Ownership

`POST /api/checkout` passes `project_id` from request body into payment metadata without verifying the user owns that project. The provisioning step filters by `user_id` so the attack does not succeed, but payment metadata is polluted.

**Severity: HIGH**

`redactPII()` is applied to synopsis text but NOT to `metadata_json`. `candidate_name`, `guide_name`, `hod_name`, `registration_no`, and `department` are sent in every generation call to Claude's US-based API.

### D3. CRITICAL: Dataset Generation Sends Synopsis Without Redaction

**File**: `lib/datasets/generate.ts:59`

Synopsis is sent to AI without passing through `redactPII()`.

### D4. CRITICAL: Previously Approved Sections Sent to AI With PII

Phase 1 (Front Matter) content includes names, registration numbers, guide names. All subsequent generation calls include this PII as context.

### D5. CRITICAL: No Privacy Policy or Terms of Service Pages

Footer links point to `#` (dead links). No `/privacy` or `/terms` routes exist.

### D6. CRITICAL: No Account Deletion Flow

No "Delete My Account" endpoint, page, or cascade delete mechanism. DPDP Act Section 12(1) right to erasure is not implemented.

### D7. CRITICAL: No Consent for AI Processing

No acknowledgement, checkbox, or consent flow at sign-up or project creation informing users their content will be processed by US-based AI services.

### D8. CRITICAL: Zero Data Retention Policies Implemented

Governance document defines comprehensive retention schedules (90-day AI conversations, 2-year audit logs, R2 cleanup). **None implemented** --- no cron jobs, no scheduled functions, no cleanup code exists.

### D9. HIGH: Edge Sentry Config Missing PII Stripping

`sentry.edge.config.ts` initialises Sentry without a `beforeSend` hook. Errors in edge middleware could leak PII. Client and server configs correctly strip PII.

### D10. HIGH: No PII Scanning on Dataset Upload

Governance document claims "Validate for PII patterns on upload" --- no implementation exists. User-uploaded datasets containing patient data pass through unchecked.

### D11. HIGH: Audit Log Retains PII After Project Deletion

`audit_log.project_id` is NOT `ON DELETE CASCADE`. Audit logs with full row snapshots (including PII) persist after project deletion.

### D12. HIGH: Cookie Consent

No cookie consent banner. PostHog analytics is opt-out (development mode only), not opt-in. DPDP Act requires explicit consent for analytics tracking.

### D13. Positive Findings

- PII redaction for synopsis (`redactPII()` covers phone, Aadhaar, email, PAN)
- PostHog uses EU endpoint with sanitised properties
- Sentry client/server configs strip PII
- Structured logger strips sensitive fields
- Webhook payloads contain no PII (only UUIDs)
- Project deletion cascades to all child tables (sections, citations, datasets, etc.)
- AI dataset generation prompts instruct "Do NOT include patient names"

---

## IV-E: Architecture & Reliability Recommendations

### E1. In-Memory State Must Move to Redis (P0)

Semaphore and rate limiter both use in-memory `Map`. They reset on server restart/deploy and are not shared across instances. This is the highest-priority infrastructure change.

**Immediate fix**: Add a TTL-based "stale job reaper" (every 60s) to evict orphaned active jobs.

### E2. PDF Storage Must Move to R2 (P0)

PDFs stored in `/tmp` are lost on every deployment. Users will see "PDF not found" after deploys.

**Fix**: Upload compiled PDFs to R2, store R2 object key in `compilations.pdf_url`, serve via signed URL redirect.

### E3. Stale Compilation Recovery (P0)

If server crashes during compilation, the compilation record is stuck at `status: "running"` forever, permanently blocking the project.

**Fix**: Add a staleness window (5 minutes) to the "already running" check. Add a periodic sweep via Inngest cron.

### E4. AI Generation Should Move to Inngest (P1)

Current long-lived SSE stream is fragile on Indian mobile networks (frequent dropouts). Split into:
1. `POST /generate` --- enqueue Inngest job, return `job_id`
2. Poll or Supabase Realtime for progress updates

Inngest is already in `package.json` (`inngest@^3.52.0`) but appears unused.

### E5. Singleton Supabase Admin Client (P1)

`createAdminSupabaseClient()` creates a new client per call. Make it a module-level singleton --- it is stateless and safe to reuse.

### E6. N+1 Citation Upserts (P1)

`lib/citations/auto-resolve.ts` performs individual `supabase.from("citations").upsert(...)` calls per citation. For ROL with 30+ citations, this is 30+ sequential DB round-trips.

**Fix**: Batch upserts --- Supabase `.upsert()` accepts an array.

### E7. PDF Viewer: Mobile Performance (P2)

Thumbnail view creates 100+ `<Page>` components simultaneously for large theses. Virtualise with `react-window`.

### E8. Bundle Size Concerns (P2)

- `three` + R3F: ~600KB (auth page 3D scene only --- ensure `next/dynamic` + `ssr: false`)
- `mermaid`: ~1.8MB (diagram rendering --- lazy load)
- `xlsx`: ~600KB (dataset parsing --- dynamic import)
- `pdfjs-dist`: ~800KB (worker loaded from unpkg CDN --- self-host in `/public/`)

### E9. Health Check Endpoint (P1)

No `/api/health` endpoint exists. Required for Coolify monitoring, uptime robots, load balancers.

### E10. Environment Variable Validation (P0)

All env vars accessed via `process.env.X!` (non-null assertion). Missing vars produce cryptic errors deep in Supabase calls.

**Fix**: Zod validation at startup in `next.config.ts`.

### E11. Offline/Connectivity Handling (P2)

Target users are Indian medical PG students on 4G mobile. No service worker, no offline caching, no optimistic UI updates. AI generation requires sustained 30-90s SSE connection.

### E12. Business Model Observations

- INR 499/month with 30-day expiry conflicts with thesis writing reality (students work in bursts with weeks between supervisor feedback)
- Consider INR 499/thesis with 90-day window instead
- Professional plan should target departments/guides, not individual students (INR 2,999 for 5 licences/semester)
- Add INR 199 trial tier covering Phase 0-1 only for quality evaluation
- Add referral system for viral growth within medical PG cohorts
